title: Hundreds take the Polar Bear Plunge at Pensacola Beach
text: LOCALParadise Beach host the annual New Year's Day Polar Bar Plunge at Pensacola BeachHundreds brave the cold Santa Rosa Sound waters behind Paradise Bar and Grill on Pensacola Beach to author: 小浪财讯
title: 鹏欣资源跌2.04%，成交额1.13亿元，主力资金净流出669.46万元|鹏欣资源_新浪财经_新浪网
text:
6月19日， 鹏欣资源 盘中下跌2.04%，截至11:25，报4.32元/股，成交1.13亿元，换手率1.29%，总市值95.60亿元。
资金流向方面，主力资金净流出669.46万元，特大单买入1205.11万元，占比10.71%，卖出649.16万元，占比5.77%；大单买入2199.33万元，占比19.55%，卖出3424.74万元，占比30.44%。
鹏欣资源今年以来股价涨31.31%，近5个交易日跌5.68%，近20日跌4.00%，近60日涨10.49%。
今年以来鹏欣资源已经2次登上龙虎榜，最近一次登上龙虎榜为4月22日。
资料显示，鹏欣环球资源股份有限公司位于上海市闵行区联航路1188号32号楼，成立日期2000年9月29日，上市日期2003年6月26日，公司主营业务涉及金属铜、金、钴等金属的开采、冶炼、加工及销售,业务范围还包括贸易、金融以及生态修复等领域。主营业务收入构成为：贸易阴极铜32.52%，自产阴极铜32.13%，镍11.47%，白银9.20%，锡锭8.38%，硫酸3.46%，铝1.42%，橡胶0.56%，氢氧化钴0.49%，其他(补充)0.24%，硅锰合金0.11%，黄金0.01%，铬矿0.01%。
鹏欣资源所属申万行业为：有色金属-工业金属-铜。所属概念板块包括：新材料、一带一路、融资融券、小金属、钴镍等。
截至3月31日，鹏欣资源股东户数8.16万，较上期减少3.08%；人均流通股24433股，较上期增加3.17%。2025年1月-3月，鹏欣资源实现营业收入15.30亿元，同比增长156.54%；归母净利润1.08亿元，同比增长283.52%。
分红方面，鹏欣资源A股上市后累计派现1.66亿元。近三年，累计派现0.00元。
机构持仓方面，截止2025年3月31日，鹏欣资源十大流通股东中，香港中央结算有限公司位居第七大流动股东，持股1562.67万股，相比上期减少1006.83万股。南方中证1000ETF（512100）位居第十大流动股东，持股1150.19万股，相比上期减少124.49万股。

author: La rédaction
title: Les novices du compostage se prennent au jeu à Fréjus - Var-Matin
text:
Pour les riverains, l’heure était au compostage. Mardi, un stand du Smiddev (Établissement public de traitement et de valorisation des déchets ménagers de l’Est-Var) était installé devant la mairie annexe de Saint-Aygulf. Deux conseillers tri, Sandy et Stéphane, vendaient des composteurs pour 10 euros et des bioseaux pour 3 euros. Ils expliquent: "Sur le marché, un compost vaut 60 euros environ. Nous voulons responsabiliser les personnes, tout en leur donnant clés en main des conseils pour bien s’en servir" . Depuis un moment, les riverains prêtent de plus en plus attention aux déchets ménagers. Le président Gilles Longo du Smiddev se félicite: "8.000 compostes individuels, à destination des propriétaires de maison ont été distribués sur le territoire" .
Idées reçues à combattre Martine est enjouée à l’idée de ramener dans son jardin un compost: "Je vais faire comme il faut, chaque jour" . Avant de repartir avec son compost, elle interroge Sandy en souriant: "Ça n’attire pas les rats? Je suis béotienne" . La conseillère tri entend beaucoup d’idées reçues, car les débutants ont tout à apprendre. La jeune femme rassure: "Si vous n’avez pas de rats en temps normal, alors il n’y a pas de raison de s’inquiéter" . Désormais confiante, cette retraitée a hâte de se lancer: "Ça va être difficile d’attendre 10 mois, le temps que le compost se forme" .
"Je peux y mettre des agrumes? Je croyais que ça rendait le sol trop acide" , s’étonne Gesine, après avoir lu la notice des aliments à composter. Sandy doit démentir beaucoup d’idées préconçues sur "l’odeur, les agrumes, les rats… Pourtant rien n’est vrai" , assure-t-elle.
"Travail de longue haleine" Josée attend son tour devant le stand du Smiddev. Elle est certaine que l’écologie est un "travail de longue haleine. Chacun devrait s’y mettre" : c’est à l’échelle individuelle que les changements s’opèrent. Aussi, la transition doit se faire main dans la main avec les générations suivantes. C’est ce qu’estime Corinne, venue avec son petit-fils: "Ses parents ont déjà un compost dans le jardin, maintenant c’est mon tour. C’est tout jeune qu’il faut leur montrer que c’est un travail d’équipe" .

author: Amelia Fabiano
title: FORECAST: Slowly warming up this week
text: PHOENIX — After a cold and wet start to the month, we are finally warming up this week. Our Valley forecast stays dry in the Valley Sunday but we could see a few more light snow showers in the four corners' area on Sunday. Buffalo Pass could get two to three inches of new snow. Overnight temperatures will remain in the upper 30s to low 40s in the Valley for another night or two before warming up into the 50s by the end next week. Expect afternoon highs back in the mid to upper 60s in Phoenix on Sunday and MLK Day. Later in the week as high pressure returns to the region, Phoenix could see temperatures back in the 70s for the first time this year. Those temperatures will stick with us through next weekend. 2024 Rainfall totals: Sky Harbor Official Rainfall: 0.03" (-0.33" from average) Valley Average (Phoenix Rainfall Index): 0.11" 2023 Rainfall totals: Sky Harbor Official Rainfall: 4.21" (-3.01" from average) Valley Average (Phoenix Rainfall Index): 5.47" Daily rainfall reports from all across the Valley can be found [here.](http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/psr/RainfallReport.php) PHOENIX IS GETTING DRIER - LOWER RAINFALL AVERAGES NOW Average Monsoon Rainfall in Phoenix (1981-2010): 2.71" of rain NEW Average Monsoon Rainfall in Phoenix (1991-2020): 2.43" of rain Average Yearly Rainfall in Phoenix (1981-2010): 8:03" of rain NEW Average Yearly Rainfall in Phoenix (1991-2020): 7.22" of rain Share your weather photos and videos with us anytime. author: kns/roj/news.de
title: Kinoprogramm Hamm: Die Film-Highlights für Kinder und Erwachsene am 12.06.2025
text:
In Hamm werden heute, am 12.06.2025, 10 Kinofilme gezeigt. Um Ihnen die Auswahl zu erleichtern, stellen wir Ihnen drei aktuelle Kino-Highlights genauer vor. Am Ende des Artikels folgt eine Übersicht der Kinos in und um Hamm mit den genauen Spielzeiten der einzelnen Filme.
Die Kino-Highlights in Hamm für Donnerstag (12.06.2025)
Zu den aktuellen Kino-Highlights zählen "Drachenzähmen leicht gemacht (2025)", "Lilo & Stitch" und "Karate Kid: Legends". Diese Filme werden am Donnerstag, 12.06.2025 am häufigsten in Hamm gezeigt:
Lilo & Stitch
Worum geht's? *"Lilo & Stitch“ ist eine Live-Action-Neuverfilmung des gleichnamigen Disney-Zeichentrickklassikers aus dem Jahr 2002. Er erzählt die witzige und rührende Geschichte eines einsamen hawaiianischen Mädchens und des flüchtigen Außerirdischen, der ihr hilft, ihre kaputte Familie zu retten. Unter der Regie von Dean Fleischer Camp, dem Oscar®-nominierten Filmemacher des Animationsfilms „Marcel the Shell with Shoes On“, spielen Maia Kealoha, Sydney Elizebeth Agudong, Billy Magnussen, Tia Carrere, Hannah Waddingham, Chris Sanders, Courtney B. Vance und Zach Galifianakis die Hauptrollen. „Lilo & Stitch“ wird von Jonathan Eirich und Dan Lin produziert, Tom Peitzman und Ryan Halprin fungieren als ausführende Produzenten.
- Wo? Cineplex Hamm (Westfalen) und CinemAhlen
Für wen? Altersfreigabe: Ab 6
Was? Genre: Komödie, Science Fiction, Familie
Wie lange? Dauer: 1 Stunden 48 Minuten
Wie gut? IMDB-Rating: 7,1 / 10
Wann? 7 Film-Vorführungen heute, am 12.06.2025 (Programm der Kinos in Hamm siehe unten)
Drachenzähmen leicht gemacht (2025)
Worum geht's? Auf der schroffen Insel Berk, wo seit Generationen eine erbitterte Feindschaft zwischen Wikingern und Drachen wütet, erweist sich Hicks als Außenseiter. Der einfallsreiche, jedoch unterschätzte Sohn von Häuptling Haudrauf widersetzt sich jahrhundertealten Traditionen, als er sich mit dem gefürchteten Nachtschatten-Drachen Ohnezahn anfreundet. Ihre außergewöhnliche Verbindung enthüllt nicht nur die wahre Natur der Drachen – sie stellt die Werteordnung aller Wikinger in Frage. Mit der ehrgeizigen und kämpferischen Astrid und dem schrulligen Waffenschmied Grobian an seiner Seite stellt sich Hicks einer Welt, die von Angst und Missverständnissen zerfressen ist. Als eine alte Bedrohung sowohl Wikinger als auch Drachen in Gefahr bringt, wird seine Freundschaft zu Ohnezahn zum Schlüssel für eine bessere Zukunft.
Wo? Cineplex Hamm (Westfalen) und CinemAhlen
Für wen? Altersfreigabe: Ab 12
Was? Genre: Action, Fantasy, Familie
Wie lange? Dauer: 2 Stunden 5 Minuten
Wie gut? IMDB-Rating: 8,1 / 10
Wann? 8 Film-Vorführungen heute, am 12.06.2025 (Programm der Kinos in Hamm siehe unten)
Karate Kid: Legends
Worum geht's? Als Kung-Fu-Wunderkind Li Fong (Ben Wang) mit seiner Mutter nach New York City zieht, findet er Halt bei einer neuen Klassenkameradin und deren Vater. Doch der Frieden ist nur von kurzer Dauer, als Li unfreiwillig die Aufmerksamkeit des lokalen Karatemeisters auf sich zieht. Um sich und seine neuen Freunde zu verteidigen, tritt Li beim ultimativen Karatewettbewerb an. Mit der Unterstützung seines Kung-Fu-Lehrers Mr. Han (Jackie Chan) und des legendären Karate Kids Daniel LaRusso (Ralph Macchio) bereitet er sich auf einen spektakulären Showdown vor, der nicht nur seine Fähigkeiten, sondern auch seinen Mut und seine Werte auf die Probe stellen soll. Zwei Äste, ein Baum: KARATE KID: LEGENDS vereint die legendären Martial-Arts-Meister einer der beliebtesten Filmreihen aller Zeiten und erzählt eine völlig neue Geschichte voller Action und Herz.
Wo? Cineplex Hamm (Westfalen) und CinemAhlen
Für wen? Altersfreigabe: Ab 12
Was? Genre: Drama, Abenteuer, Action
Wie lange? Dauer: 1 Stunden 35 Minuten
Wann? 4 Film-Vorführungen heute, am 12.06.2025 (Programm der Kinos in Hamm siehe unten)
Aktuelle Kinofilme für Kinder
Sie wollen mit ihren Kindern oder Enkeln ins Kino gehen? Das Kinoprogramm in Hamm hat Kinderfilme unterschiedlichster Genres im Angebot. Ob Komödie, Fantasy, Science Fiction oder Abenteuer - hier ist sicher für jeden kleinen Kinofan etwas dabei. Diese Kinderfilme laufen aktuell in Hamm:
- Drachenzähmen leicht gemacht (2025) (FSK: 12, 125 Minuten)
- Ein Minecraft Film (FSK: 12, 101 Minuten)
- Lilo & Stitch (FSK: 6, 108 Minuten)

author: www.ETHRWorld.com
title: Green industry boom: Is it the next big hub for massive jobs?, ETHRWorld
text: The current landscape of green jobs is poised for growth in the coming years, as companies become highly ESG compliant and help achieve India’s goal of net zero emissions by the year 2070.India is undergoing a change which is driven by a surging commitment to environmental responsibility. A recent IBM survey pointed out that 82 percent of Indian business leaders are actively seeking to hire professionals with expertise in green and sustainability technologies. This translates to a massive jobs bonanza in the eco-space, with demand far outstripping current talent pools.Researchers have said that from renewable energy solutions to waste management innovations, the gamut of green jobs encompasses diverse roles. Wind turbine technicians, solar panel installers, green building designers, and carbon footprint analysts are just a few examples of the in-demand workforce of the future. This hiring spree extends beyond niche sectors, with established companies revamping their operations and seeking sustainability experts to spearhead the transition.In this overall context, ETHRWorld interacted with some industry experts in order to understand more about this trend.What does data say?As per a survey by Naukri.com, the average year on year growth in green jobs was around 27 percent in Oct 2023 vs Oct 2022. According to Sachin Alug, CEO, NLB Services, 30 million green jobs are expected to be created within India by 2050. Globally, green talent share increased from less than 10 percent to about 14 percent within 6 years.The current landscape of green jobs is poised for growth in the coming years, as companies become highly ESG compliant and help achieve India’s goal of net zero emissions by the year 2070.Alug adds that salary packages for professionals with skills in sustainability across industries have been reported to be anywhere between Rs 10 lakh per annum and Rs 25 LPA.Also, since the domain of green jobs is in a nascent stage, there is a surge in the demand for skilled professionals consisting mainly of millennials and Gen Z.Current landscape of green skill jobs in IndiaBrijesh Narang, VP - HR, Indian Energy Exchange (an organisation at the forefront of India's energy transition), says that the current landscape of green jobs in India is undergoing a dynamic shift driven by the nation's ambitious goal of achieving 500 GW of renewable energy capacity by 2030. Currently, different sectors are at various stages of formulating and implementing policies and strategies to promote sustainability, leading to the positive outcome of green job creation in India. Narang adds that as businesses in India embrace sustainable practices, there is also a growing need to upskill and reskill the existing workforce in green skills to bridge the human resource gap.Furthermore, the incorporation of green skills into academic frameworks and government initiatives like the Green Skill Development Programme further support this transformative journey.“The future of work is undeniably green, with Environmental, Social and Governance (ESG) considerations becoming non-negotiable for enterprises. India's capacity to address environmental challenges and embrace sustainability is intricately linked to the integration of green skills across industries,” he says.On the same, KT Rao, Head - People & Culture, RHI Magnesita India, West Asia & Africa Region, mentions that the green skill landscape in India is burgeoning, with immense potential driven by policy tailwinds and growing investor interest. However, according to Rao, the talent pool lags behind demand, particularly for niche specialisations like renewable energy project management, green hydrogen engineering, recycling of heavy industrial material. “While upskilling the existing workforce is crucial, it is also important that we close the gap through robust industry-academia partnerships and targeted skilling initiatives,” Rao says.Skill sets in demandNarang of IEX highlights that as the demand for renewable energy continues to rise, organisations are searching for individuals with a solid technical foundation that includes a profound understanding of scientific principles, global energy markets and regulatory policies. Ongoing learning through certifications and active participation in industry workshops further enhances a candidate's attractiveness in this dynamic and impactful field.Also, it should be noted that the significance of green skills extends beyond the energy sector, as sustainability emerges as a global priority across various industries. The increasing opportunities for professionals with green skills align with the need to champion environmental stewardship and contribute to the creation of a more sustainable and resilient future.Rao of RHI Magnesita points out that organisations across the spectrum seek a blend of technical expertise and soft skills. Furthermore, a deep understanding of sustainable technologies like solar PV, green steel, recycling and energy management is essential. But equally important are problem-solving, data analysis and communication skills to navigate complex projects and collaborate across diverse teams. Climate innovation mindset and a passion for sustainability are always an added advantage.Attracting talent in the industryExperts say that creating accessible educational programmes, offering financial incentives like scholarships or grants for related studies, fostering partnerships between industries and academic institutions, and highlighting success stories of individuals making a positive impact in these fields can all inspire interest in sustainability careers.Rao of RHI Magnesita explains that attracting talent requires a two-pronged approach.Firstly, one needs to showcase the exciting and impactful nature of green careers through various forums and platforms such as campus activities, alumni connect, employer branding and hackathons. Then the focus should be on highlighting how sustainability professionals are at the forefront of tackling climate change and building a greener future and how they hold the potential to inspire the youth. Secondly, organisations need to make green jobs accessible through scholarships, loan assistance and targeted outreach programmes to non-traditional talent pools, which can also ensure inclusivity and diversity in the green workforce.“There is a need for leaders who can make well-informed decisions that strike a balance between corporate goals and environmental sustainability, especially in light of the pressing global climate crisis. Identifying and cultivating talent capable of seeing opportunities for sustainable practices—like energy-saving and waste-reduction projects—becomes crucial to achieving both organisational performance and favourable environmental results,” says Narang.Addressing the challengesChallenges in acquiring green skills include a lack of specialised training, constantly evolving technologies, and costs. At the organisational level, investing in training programmes, partnerships with educational institutions, and offering incentives can help. Industry wide efforts like standardised training and government support through subsidies or collaboration initiatives can address these obstacles on a broader scale.Rao of RHI Magnesita says that organisations face hurdles in adopting green practices, such as resistance to change due to unfamiliarity and fear, budget constraints hindering sustainable investments, and inadequate leadership commitment. At the industry level, challenges encompass the absence of standardised green practices, competitive pressures favouring short-term gains over green investments, limited collaboration hindering resource sharing, and regulatory uncertainty complicating sustainability planning.Overcoming these challenges is crucial for developing a skilled workforce capable of contributing to sustainable development amid a dynamic job market. Narang of IEX highlights that there is a significant shortage of qualified green talent that poses a challenge for companies adding green jobs. This gap highlights a crucial issue: the difficulty in finding individuals with the necessary green skills. Transitioning to a sustainable, low-carbon economy requires a workforce with these skills, and the current deficit could hinder efforts to combat climate change.He suggests that to address this challenge, companies should invest in education and training programmes focused on green skills. This entails allocating resources for curriculum and training modules aligned with the latest developments in sustainable technologies. From a diversity, equity and inclusion (DE&I) perspective, leaders can promote mentorship and sponsorship programmes to support women and underrepresented groups in gaining the skills and experience needed for leadership roles in green industries.Measures adopted by companiesCompanies like IEX have adopted a diversified strategy to address the sustainability skills gap by prioritising the development of talent through internal training programmes. Recently, IEX launched an e-learning portal, encouraging employees to acquire new skills and apply them within the organisation. The integration of digital skills aligns with evolving expectations and underscores technology's crucial role. Knowledge sharing sessions foster a collaborative learning environment.Moreover, as India’s inaugural carbon-neutral exchange, IEX has gone beyond training by ingraining sustainability into its corporate culture and daily operations. Collaborating with BluSmart Mobility, the company is providing employees access to emission-free transportation.Diversity in the industryExperts feel that there is still time for women to take charge in the industry, although with advancements many changes are being noticed.Rao of RHI Magnesita says that diversity and inclusion ratios in green jobs in India might vary across sectors and regions. However, efforts are being made to encourage D&I in these sectors, promoting equal opportunities for all individuals.Over the past two and a half years, RHI Magnesita has made progress, increasing the representation of women employees from 3 percent to 7 percent. Now, the company has set an ambitious target for the future, aiming to achieve a 15 percent representation of women in the workforce by 2025.RHI Magnesita’s commitment to correcting the gender imbalance is evident in its strategic approach. This proactive stance reflects a recognition of the value that gender diversity brings to the workplace, fostering a more inclusive and varied perspective.Narang of IEX too adds that the organisation has seen significant growth in the participation of female colleagues in the last 3-4 years. While core industries have typically been male-dominated, there has been a tremendous shift, with women now actively taking on critical roles at IEX in areas such as market operations, finance (investor relations), technology, and more.Read alsoLooking Back: How feasible is the call for a 70-hour work week?Shh... Careers altered! What new workplace trend ‘quiet cutting’ is all about?How HRs can do damage control in an organisation suffering from toxic work cultureOpenAI Drama: What strategies can companies implement while facing leadership transitions?

author: Michael Pontrelli
title: L’allarme di Yuval Noah Harari: l’intelligenza artificiale ci condanna a vivere senza riposo
text:
L’allarme di Yuval Noah Harari: l’intelligenza artificiale ci condanna a vivere senza riposo
Per il celebre storico e filosofo israeliano l’avvento dell’AI segna il secondo punto di svolta nella storia dell’universo
In una conversazione con il giornalista Andrew Ross Sorkin pubblicata dal canale You Tube Big Thing, il celebre storico e filosofo israeliano Yuval Noah Harari ha fatto il punto sullo sviluppo dell’intelligenza artificiale. Un’analisi diversa da tutto ciò che solitamente si sente in giro in merito all’AI e che conferma la profondità del pensiero dell’autore di Sapiens (Da animali a Dei. Breve storia dell'umanità) e di Homo Deus (Breve storia del futuro).
Secondo Harari, la storia dell'universo, per come la conosciamo, può essere sintetizzata in due momenti chiave. Il primo risale a circa 4 miliardi di anni fa, con l’emergere delle prime forme di vita organica sulla Terra, che hanno dominato l’evoluzione per miliardi di anni, attraversando fasi con organismi semplici come le amebe fino ad arrivare a specie complesse come i dinosauri e gli esseri umani. Nonostante i progressi tutta l’evoluzione è rimasta confinata al regno organico.
Il secondo momento di svolta nella storia dell’universo per Harari è avvenuto con l'avvento dell'intelligenza artificiale, che rappresenta l’inizio di una nuova fase: l'evoluzione inorganica. Harari paragona l’IA attuale, inclusi strumenti come GPT-4, alle amebe di questa nuova era, sottolineando che siamo solo agli albori di un processo evolutivo che potrebbe portare alla comparsa di forme inorganiche sempre più complesse.
In questo contesto, personalità come Elon Musk e Sam Altman per lo studioso israeliano assumono un ruolo centrale, poiché il loro contributo potrebbe segnare un punto di svolta fondamentale nella storia dell'universo.
Per Harari i protagonisti dello sviluppo dell'intelligenza artificiale provano un misto di ambizione ma anche di paura per quello che stanno creando. Sono profondamente consapevoli del potenziale dell’IA, incluso il suo possibile impatto distruttivo, e questa consapevolezza li spaventa. Dall’altro però prevale un atteggiamento in cui si percepiscono come i "buoni" della situazione, convinti di agire con maggiore responsabilità rispetto ad altri che potrebbero sviluppare queste tecnologie senza scrupoli.
Harari percepisce una tensione crescente tra il mondo organico, rappresentato dagli esseri umani, e il sistema digitale inorganico, costituito da algoritmi, intelligenza artificiale e computer. A differenza degli esseri viventi, che seguono ritmi naturali scanditi da cicli di attività e riposo, questi sistemi inorganici non si fermano mai, restando sempre attivi. La grande sfida, secondo lo storico, è capire se sarà il mondo organico ad adattarsi a queste macchine o viceversa. Attualmente, sembra che siano gli esseri umani a dover adeguarsi, costretti a vivere in una condizione di "sempre acceso". Questa trasformazione per l’autore di Sapiens e Homo Deus ha conseguenze significative perché di fatto condanna gli uomini a vivere senza riposo.
Harari a titolo esemplificativo prende come riferimento il mondo finanziario. Finora mercati come Wall Street hanno operato secondo ritmi organici, con orari definiti che permettono agli operatori di staccare e recuperare. Ma l'avvento dell'intelligenza artificiale consentirebbe già oggi l'introduzione di mercati attivi 24 ore al giorno per 7 giorni la settimana e questo cambierebbe drasticamente le regole del gioco, rendendo impossibile per banchieri e finanzieri trovare momenti di riposo. Questa ipotesi e altre simili, conclude lo studioso, rappresentano una pressione enorme per l'umanità, chiamata a competere con macchine che non conoscono pause.

author: @Dailyhuntapp
title: Chiltern Arts 2024 Festival To Blend Music, Literature In Human Stories Theme
text:
Chiltern Arts has unveiled 'Human Stories' as the central theme for its eagerly anticipated 2024 festival, set to captivate audiences from May 10th to May 17th. This unique event promises a rich blend of musical performances, poetry readings, and literature sessions, featuring a lineup of distinguished artists. Among the musical talents are The Gesualdo Six, I Fagiolini, Fenella Humphreys, and the Carducci String Quartet. Literary enthusiasts will be delighted by appearances from Roger McGough and James Runcie.
The festival is not just a celebration of arts but also an educational venture with its ListenUp & ListenIn outreach initiative aimed at inspiring young minds aged 9 to 14. This initiative is a testament to the festival's commitment to fostering a love for culture among the younger generation. Naomi Taylor, Founder and Creative Director, expressed her enthusiasm for the project's pilot phase, highlighting the importance of cultural education in building a resilient cultural sector. To further this cause, the festival encourages supporters to 'Sponsor a Seat', enabling more children to experience the magic of the arts.
In a novel approach to scheduling, the festival will span several locations, dedicating two full days each to Henley-on-Thames, Princes Risborough and surrounding villages, before concluding in Hughenden and Marlow. Attendees can avail of a 20% discount on tickets for each location with festival passes.
The festivities kick off in Henley with an Afternoon Tea aboard The New Orleans featuring poet Roger McGough. The evening will see performances by Huw Wiggin, Noriko Ogawa, and Oliver Wass. The following day promises an eclectic mix of music and poetry with performances by the Brompton Quartet, the Natrio Trumpet Trio, and The Gesualdo Six, including a special rendition of Fauré's Requiem by the Chiltern Arts Festival Chorus.
As the festival moves to Princes Risborough, attendees can look forward to French Fables performed by a theorbo and viola da gamba duo at Holy Trinity Church. A film screening about Fanny Mendelssohn featuring Isata Kanneh-Mason will be followed by an exploration of Bach's world through performances by Fenella Humphreys and James Runcie. The day concludes with a guided walk and a talk on Shostakovich by BBC broadcaster Stephen Johnson, leading into an evening concert with the Carducci Quartet and actor Anton Lesser.
The final leg of the festival in Hughenden features poetry and spoken word by Cathi Rae and performances by the Alinde Wind Quintet. The grand finale in Marlow will be marked by a choral performance by I Fagiolini, showcasing 17th Century Italian masterpieces.
This year's Chiltern Arts Festival is poised to offer an unforgettable journey through music and literature under the banner of 'Human Stories'. For more information and to book tickets, interested parties are encouraged to visit chilternarts.com.
